riflemen will journey to Gettysburg tomorrow to match

GOUCHER'S ANTIQUATED RULES
There is a strikingly close .analogy between Congress and the
powers-that-be at Goucher. Strange? Not at all! Congress
attempts to regulate morals by legislation; Goucher pursues the
same course.
The hypocrisy of the Goucher regulations have been brought out
more strongly than ever this year, perhaps, because the local papers
have been more successful in securing the news of punishments
meted out to the lassies for such very execrable sins as smoking.
In reality, however, this year is no exception. It is a more or less
well-known fact that Goucher students disobey what they feel to
be an unfair rule by smoking whenever an opportunity presents
itself. Not only do they grasp every opportunity to smoke, but
they "sign out," ostensibly to spend an evening reading or listening
to the radio at some girl's home, and then attend parties till the
wee hours of the morning.
We can't blame the girls. They fully realize that the so-called
Social Regulations have become anachronisms, and, therefore, pay
no attention to them. Unfortunately, as always happens in cases
where perfectly harmless things are prohibited, practices which are
innocuous enough in moderation are carried to extremes.
Any rules that are laid down by the authorities at a girls' college
are the result of a feeling of responsibility for the students' welfare. Well and good. When the rules are totally out of tune with
generally accepted notions of contemporary morals, however, the
pendulum swings the other way. And as long as Goucher makes'
it sin to smoke or to go riding with "gentlemen" after six o'clock,
the Baltimore papers will continue to print stories of girls being
put on the restricted list!

IS DEBATING DEAD?
The steadily decreasing interest in debating at Johns Hopkins
-has been evoking comment as to the advisability of its continuance.
Formerly, an intercollegiate debate would draw fairly large crowds,
-and interclass debates would always be attended with considerable
enthusiasm. Now, the few intercollegiate contests that have been
held have been particularly significant both by the small number
Of people who have been present at the debates and the complete
lack of interest in them on the campus.
The situation is perhaps worse in the interclass debates. The
number of candidates for the senior team this year was actually
less than the number of men required: men had to be recruited
and almost begged to take their places on the team. And even
then, up to within a week before the debate, no preparation whatsoever had been made. If it were not for the more or less lucrative
prizes offered, we doubt seriously whether there would be either
a senior team or a junior team.
We know perfectly well that there are always some who don't
like attention to be called to the fact that any existing institution"
is atrophying. They say that unless the critic can offer constructive criticism, he would do better to keep quiet. In the case of
debating at Hopkins,however,we believe that the continued apathy
of the student body has proved that the most constructive criticism
that can be offered is the recommendation that debating be dropped
from the roster of student activities. -

GOUCHER'S ANTIQUATED RULES
There is a strikingly close .analogy between Congress and the
powers-that-be at Goucher. Strange? Not at all! Congress
attempts to regulate morals by legislation; Goucher pursues the
same course.
The hypocrisy of the Goucher regulations have been brought out
more strongly than ever this year, perhaps, because the local papers
have been more successful in securing the news of punishments
meted out to the lassies for such very execrable sins as smoking.
In reality, however, this year is no exception. It is a more or less
well-known fact that Goucher students disobey what they feel to
be an unfair rule by smoking whenever an opportunity presents
itself. Not only do they grasp every opportunity to smoke, but
they "sign out," ostensibly to spend an evening reading or listening
to the radio at some girl's home, and then attend parties till the
wee hours of the morning.
We can't blame the girls. They fully realize that the so-called
Social Regulations have become anachronisms, and, therefore, pay
no attention to them. Unfortunately, as always happens in cases
where perfectly harmless things are prohibited, practices which are
innocuous enough in moderation are carried to extremes.
Any rules that are laid down by the authorities at a girls' college
are the result of a feeling of responsibility for the students' welfare. Well and good. When the rules are totally out of tune with
generally accepted notions of contemporary morals, however, the
pendulum swings the other way. And as long as Goucher makes'
it sin to smoke or to go riding with "gentlemen" after six o'clock,
the Baltimore papers will continue to print stories of girls being
put on the restricted list!

IS DEBATING DEAD?
The steadily decreasing interest in debating at Johns Hopkins
-has been evoking comment as to the advisability of its continuance.
Formerly, an intercollegiate debate would draw fairly large crowds,
-and interclass debates would always be attended with considerable
enthusiasm. Now, the few intercollegiate contests that have been
held have been particularly significant both by the small number
Of people who have been present at the debates and the complete
lack of interest in them on the campus.
The situation is perhaps worse in the interclass debates. The
number of candidates for the senior team this year was actually
less than the number of men required: men had to be recruited
and almost begged to take their places on the team. And even
then, up to within a week before the debate, no preparation whatsoever had been made. If it were not for the more or less lucrative
prizes offered, we doubt seriously whether there would be either
a senior team or a junior team.
We know perfectly well that there are always some who don't
like attention to be called to the fact that any existing institution"
is atrophying. They say that unless the critic can offer constructive criticism, he would do better to keep quiet. In the case of
debating at Hopkins,however,we believe that the continued apathy
of the student body has proved that the most constructive criticism
that can be offered is the recommendation that debating be dropped
from the roster of student activities. -
